string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: scenarios verbal and non-verbal strategies the following scenarios demonstrate three different approaches to simultaneous use of verbal and non-verbal strategies in the classroom. to access a scenario, select one of the year level buttons below,then use the arrow buttons on the bottom of the slide tonavigate the scenario. years f–2 years f–2 years f–2 years f–2 years f–2 years f–2 years 3–6 years 3–6 years 3–6 years 3–6 years 3–6 years 3–6 years 7+ years 7+ years 7+ years 7+ years 7+ years 7+ select a scenario to begin.

give student’s time to learn from watching their peers. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2 give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. scenario ms. r noticed when beginning an explicit teaching session with her foundation class, students were increasingly taking longer to be ready, interrupting the instructional time available. one morning, ms. r asked the students to make their way to the mat to start the new lesson. many students were slow to pack up their previous task and start to make their way to the floor. students were rolling around on the floor while waiting, others were chatting and not ready to listen. what should ms. r do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue.

give student’s time to learn from watching their peers. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. give students time to learn from watching their peers. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. reduce the number of transitions in a teaching session. scenario please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. ms. r noticed when beginning an explicit teaching session with her foundation class, students were increasingly taking longer to be ready, interrupting the instructional time available. one morning, ms. r asked the students to make their way to the mat to start the new lesson. many students were slow to pack up their previous task and start to make their way to the floor. students were rolling around on the floor while waiting, others were chatting and not ready to listen. what should ms. r do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. r recognises that the students have not been at school for very long and come to the classroom with different needs and at different levels of readiness for learning. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

possible solution ms. r decided to let things go and accept the fact that some students would take longer to transition between different types of learning. she hoped that by watching their peers who were doing the right thing, those who weren’t would learn what to do and start to transition in a more efficient way. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

this is not the best solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. at first, ms. r allowed the students as much time as needed to transition between learning activities. after a week, it became clear that student behaviour was not changing through watching their peers. ms. r recognised that the students who were doing the right thing were getting frustrated at having to wait longer and longer for the learning to start, and were beginning to engage in unproductive behaviour. valuable learning time was being lost. after some reflection, ms. r decided she needed to rethink her approach. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

context ms. r knows that the use of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies can support students to follow routines and engage in productive behaviour, reducing wasted learning time and helping to free up working memory to focus on learning. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

possible solution ms. r’s strategies included the following: clear communication in a calm and confident voice, ms. r uses the “cue to start” prompt, “1,2,3,4 are you sitting on the floor, 5,6,7,8 hands in laps, sitting up straight. positive acknowledgment ms. r gestures to ali and says “i can see that ali is showing me they are ready to start learning because they’re sitting still and quietly on the floor and facing the front”. these verbal strategies could be used several times, acknowledging a different student each time and then repeating the rhyme, giving the students multiple opportunities to demonstrate their readiness. select the blue ‘x’ button above to close the strategies. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2 possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. r decided to use a combination of verbal strategies (clear communication and positive acknowledgement) alongside non-verbal strategies (pause time in between the repetitions) to re-engage students and provide corrective feedback. select the button below to see the ms. r’s strategies. strategies strategies strategies strategies this reminded students of the appropriate behaviours to use when making their way to a whole-class learning space. ms. r uses these verbal strategies several times, acknowledging a different student each time and then repeating the rhyme, giving the students multiple opportunities to demonstrate their readiness. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

well done! this is a good solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. or, you can select the ‘introduction’ button below to close this scenario and select another year level to explore. well done! introduction introduction introduction introduction overall outcome ms. r was able to maintain the flow of the lesson between individual and whole-class tasks. she noticed a significant improvement in the students’ ability to move from independent to whole-class activities, which reduced the time students had to engage in unproductive behaviour. ms. r noticed that the classroom was calmer and she was spending more time teaching her students. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. r recognises that the students are young, and wonders if they should reduce the number of times students are expected to move between their desks and the floor. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. ms. r decided to conduct lessons with a maximum of one transition per teaching session. teaching sessions were between 1 and 2 hours long. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

this is not the best solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome at first, ms. r felt she gained extra teaching time, as less time was spent on transitioning between learning spaces. however, after a couple of days ms. r found it more challenging to plan engaging lessons around the learning space, rather than letting the type of teaching dictate the space. students started to lose interest in the lessons and valuable learning time was being lost. after some reflection, ms. r decided she needed to rethink her approach. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years f–2

use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. increase opportunities for student choice. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. scenario please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. mr. m noticed an increase in off-task behaviours from students in his year 4 class. it tended to be worse when students had the opportunity to choose the learning space and way of working to achieve the learning outcomes. some students would choose to work together on the floor, others at a table. several students liked to work either independently or with a partner, and one larger group preferred to work together in an outdoor area just outside the classroom. what should mr. m do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. increase opportunities for student choice. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. give students less choice of learning space and way of working. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. increase opportunities for student choice. scenario please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. mr. m noticed an increase in off-task behaviours from students in his year 4 class. it tended to be worse when students had the opportunity to choose the learning space and way of working to achieve the learning outcomes. some students would choose to work together on the floor, others at a table. several students liked to work either independently or with a partner, and one larger group preferred to work together in an outdoor area just outside the classroom. what should mr. m do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

context mr. m recognises the importance of students as active participants in their learning. he knows the use of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies can support students to follow expectations and engage productively in learning. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

possible solution mr. m used a variety of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies to address unproductive behaviour. he started the lesson with clear communication and voice control to set the expectations, including noise level, movement options and time. he reminded the students that "stop, look, listen," spoken strongly and assertively is the cue to stop work and pay attention. he checked their understanding of this before they began work. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mr. m used the prompt "name, pause and thanks" to acknowledge students as they responded. once the whole class was attentive, mr. m reminded students of the expectations and re-directed them back to the learning. he used proactive praise to acknowledge productive behaviour. mr. m continued to move around the classroom, maintaining proximity, giving proactive praise and addressing any off-task, unproductive behaviour. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

well done! this is a good solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. or, you can select the ‘introduction’ button below to close this scenario and select another year level to explore. well done! introduction introduction introduction introduction overall outcome mr. m noticed a significant improvement in student on-task, productive behaviour. lessons were calmer and quieter and students were producing work of a higher quality. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

context mr. m questions the approach he has taken to lessons, and wonders if he needs to reduce the number of opportunities for students to have some choice in where and how they learn. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

possible solution mr. m decided to change the way he had students engage with content, and planned lessons that involved students only working independently when they were ready to complete more complex activities. he explained the changes to the class and gave them his reasons. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

this is not the best solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome at first, mr. m noticed a significant reduction in the time he had to spend managing unproductive behaviours. however, after a week, some students began to comment that they were bored and wanted to be able to work with their peers on occasions. the quality of work started to reduce and mr. m noticed that class discussions were not as rich as they had been, and some students were less motivated to learn. after some reflection, mr. m. decided he needed to rethink his approach. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

context mr. m knows the value of providing students with some choice in their learning. he considers perhaps the unproductive behaviour is not as bad as he thinks it is, and wonders if the students need more opportunities for choice. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

possible solution mr. m decided to plan more lessons with opportunities for students to select how they worked. he wondered if more experience would help students understand expected behaviours. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

this is not the best solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome at first, mr. m was able to let go of his frustration and allow the students to work (or not) as they chose. after a week, he recognised that levels of unproductive behaviour were increasing, not decreasing, and valuable learning time was being lost. after some reflection, mr. m. decided he needed to rethink his approach. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 3–6

have the classroom open when students arrived. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. mx. p teaches a year 9 class. they usually wait for mx. p to open the learning space area before entering, however, mx. p is noticing that students are becoming slower to arrive, increasingly noisy when they get there and are unprepared for class. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. scenario please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress what should mx. p do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

have the classroom open when students arrived. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. have the classroom open when students arrive. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. use a combination of appropriate verbal and non-verbal strategies. scenario please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. mx. p teaches a year 9 class. they usually wait for mx. p to open the learning space area before entering, however, mx. p is noticing that students are becoming slower to arrive, increasingly noisy when they get there and are unprepared for class. what should mx. p do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

context mx. p knows that students need maximum time for learning and wonders if they need to arrive at the classroom earlier. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

possible solution mx. p decided to try and arrive earlier to have the classroom open when students arrived. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

this is not the best solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome while mx. p was pleased the unproductive behaviour was no longer occurring outside of the classroom, students were still arriving late and unprepared and were entering the classroom in a disorderly way, and were not ready to learn when inside. it was taking them a significant amount of time to settle the students, and they were always feeling flustered with the added pressure to move between their own classes quickly. after some reflection, mx. p decided they needed to rethink their approach. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

context mx. p knows that setting expectations supports productive behaviour, and that students who engage in unproductive behaviour need some form of consequence. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

possible solution mx. p outlined to their classes the impact their behaviour is having on the time for teaching and learning. they explained that they are going to enforce the expectations through increasing the use of consequences for unproductive behaviour. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

this is not the best solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome mx. p noticed an immediate improvement in student behaviour and their level of readiness to learn when they entered the classroom. however, after a couple of days students started to react against the consequences being imposed and pushed the boundaries even further. mx. p’s relationship with the students was breaking down as they were spending a significant amount of time reacting to students in a negative manner. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. p noticed that they were becoming more and more frustrated, and they were feeling exhausted and unmotivated. mx. p realised this wasn’t an effective way of supporting the students to understand the expectations. after some reflection, mx. p decided they needed to rethink their approach. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

context mx. p recognises the importance of students being ready to learn when they enter a classroom. they know the use of appropriate verbal strategies can support students to follow expectations. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. p decided to use a range of verbal strategies. they planned for and frequently used authentic and behaviour-specific proactive praise when observing students engaging in expected behaviours. when praising students, mx. p made sure they used positive and assertive voice control. as students entered the classroom, mx. p started greeting them individually and offered positive acknowledgements when appropriate. for example, they would say “welcome …. thank you for making your way quietly. i can see you are almost ready to start. i appreciate the way you have found a seat quickly.” at the end of the lesson, mx. p used a 3-step instructional sequence (who, what, when) and redirection to focus students on their next lesson transition. “ok. it’s time for everyone to pack up now (who) and remember to move quietly and safely (what) to your next lesson (when)”. this helped establish a clear routine. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+

introduction introduction introduction introduction well done! this is a good solution. select the blue ‘x’ above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. or, you can select the ‘introduction’ button below to close this scenario and select another year level to explore. well done! overall outcome over a period of a week, mx. p noticed an improvement in the behaviour of students as they waited for them to open up the classroom. they were eager to say hello and entered the classroom ready to learn. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: verbal and non-verbal strategies | years 7+
